results.title: Constructing reality: a film on film
results.creator_credit: David Altschul, Gilbert Altschul Productions and Journal Films
results.brief_description: The five key elements of film construction - film time, film space, perspective, rhythm and sound are discussed as we construct a film within a film about a sports car race. The film shows how the film-maker planned, photographed and edited sequences.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Altschul, Gilbert Altschul Productions and Journal Films

results.title: Constructing farm dams
results.brief_description: In some parts of Australia, farmers have to rely on seasonal rains for their annual water requirements, with the result that crops are often ruined due to low rainfall. In areas with a suitable clay sub-soil, earth dams can be constrcuted to conserve water to improve pastures and increase production. This film describes the principles and methods of dam construction recommended by the Water Conservation and Irrigation Commission of New South Wales.

results.title: Conspiracy in Kyoto
results.brief_description: Conspiracy in Kyoto is based on one of the most famous of the narrative scrolls painted by the Japanese in the 12th, 13th and 14th centuries. This scroll, the “Ban Dainagon”, painted by Mitsunaga in 1175, is the story of an innocent man, unjustly accused of a capital crime, who wins his vindication. The film describes in detail the burning of the Imperial Gate, which constitutes the actual crime, and the various episodes connected with the search for the culprit.

results.title: Considering crystals
results.creator_credit: Michael Crossfield, Peter Griffiths, Unilever Films and Viewpoint Productions
results.brief_description: Looks at the way a molecular structure can build up through the repeated unit cell into a crystal lattice. Explains the main types of bonding which produce different types of crystal structure; it then goes on to consider some of the ways in which crystal structure is controlled in practice. The film illustrates its points with examples ranging from the alloying of steel and copper to the control of polymorphism in fats and the crystalline structure of polymers in plastics and man-made fibres.

results.title: Conserving our soil today
results.brief_description: Techniques and experiments in soil conservation including the use of plastic sheets to retain moisture, subsoil mulching, new fertilisers, and experiments with artificial rain to determine patterns of soil erosion. The more common methods of conservation; the dependence of the individual on the products of the soil.

results.title: Conserving our mineral resources today
results.brief_description: As our industrial society consumes more mineral resources, the decreasing supply of such irreplaceable minerals as coal, oil, stone and metals make conservation a problem for today. Conservation for better living requires development of renewable resources such as waterpower to conserve non-renewable coal, more efficient mining and extraction methods, and new resources of power, such as nuclear and solar energy.

results.title: Conserving our forests today
results.brief_description: Provides a look at what was considered recent advances in forest conservation in 1960, such as the use of helicopters and plastic hose in fire-fighting, new insecticides and chemicals for the control of disease, aerial seeding and mechanical transplanting. The value of forests for timber, grazing, water, recreation; how forest lands are being protected and renewed for the future.

results.title: The Pollution crisis
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Conserving Our Environment”.
As population increases, waste products are discarded in such increasing quantities that they cannot be absorbed by the environment, and pollution reaches crisis proportions. Shows some of the ways we are polluting our land, sea and air, and offers various solutions for protecting our environment.

results.title: Use and reuse
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Conserving Our Environment”
How does a living organism relate to its environment? Dean learns about the ecological systems of the earth as he observes the ecological system of a fishbowl. He discovers how humans relate to their environment - how we use it, destroy it and restore it.
